posts.text: Even as it has defended democracy Brazil’s supreme court has become more prickly, sometimes casting criticism of its members as an attack on democracy itself https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2026/02/24/brazils-high-court-is-caught-up-in-a-vast-scandal
posts.author: TheEconomist

posts.text:
Global investors are diversifying away from US stocks:

For every $100 flowing into global equity funds in 2026, only $26 is now going to US stocks, the lowest allocation since 2020.

The proportion of capital flowing to US funds is on track for its 2nd consecutive annual decline.

By comparison, at the 2022 peak, this percentage was 3.5 times higher, at 92%.

International equity funds have attracted a record +$65 billion in inflows on average per week over the last 4 weeks.

This is largely driven by South Korea, where investors poured +$18 billion into Korean equities over the last 6 weeks, the most on record.

Global investors are diversifying outside of the US.

posts.text:
I would argue the opposite… Hydrograph is an Nanotech IP company that has been lost and unappreciated because it’s been marketing on the CSE amongst shitco miners.  

The audience is completely clueless to what Hydrograph $hg $hgraf is all about.   

Jaded investor group that doesn’t have a clue how to value it or if they should believe in it. So they have to wait for EPA approvals and other major milestones to see the forest through the trees. 

It’s moving to the Nasdaq and is now marketing to a world that is desperate for nanomaterials and graphene tech. Especially high tech applications and advanced biotech 

Very few mining guys got it… only the curious deep dive types.   Jay was willing to look. Guys like Doug Casey and Jim Rogers have been on the hunt for a viable graphene solution for ages.  They get it.
